Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a concrete proposal for Pytheus to design a hybrid-regime teleportation network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to teleport an unknown qubit at node A (detector 0) to node C (detector 1).  \n\u2013 The Bell measurement at A is implemented by two weak-excitation SPDC pair sources whose photons meet in a small linear-optics network and are post-selected on four ancilla detectors (2,3,4,5).  \n\u2013 The entangled resource between B and C is generated by two on-demand single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter coupling), each feeding into modes that are combined interferometrically before reaching detectors at B\u2019s station and C\u2019s output port.  \n\u2013 We enforce that no SPDC source directly populates C and no single-emitter directly populates A by using `removed_connections`.  \n\u2013 Upon coincidence detection in the four ancilla modes, the state at A is teleported to C.  \n  \nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n  emitters/sources: [SPDC1][SPDC2]   [SE1][SE2]  \n  interferometer :   [  Bell-meas unit  ]   [  resource-prep unit ]  \n  detectors       : [0 (A)] [1 (C)] [2][3][4][5 (ancillas)]  \n  \nConfig for Pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Hybrid teleportation: SPDC Bell-measurement + single-emitter entangled resource\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid-teleport\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 15,\n  in_nodes: [0],\n  out_nodes: [1],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\", \"11\"],\n  single_emitters: [2, 3],           # sources SE1, SE2\n  removed_connections: [              # forbid direct links SPDC\u2192C and SE\u2192A\n    [1, 4], [1, 5], \n    [0, 6], [0, 7]\n  ],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  unicolor: false\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a standard quantum\u2010teleportation circuit, merely substituting two SPDC sources for the Bell measurement and two on-demand emitters for the entangled pair. Teleportation itself is far from novel (and many hybrid light\u2013matter teleportation experiments have already been studied), so this target does not introduce a new network primitive or fundamentally new effect beyond what is in the literature.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Teleportation alone\u2014even using mixed SPDC and single-emitter resources\u2014is not sufficiently novel for a PRL-level network primitive. To improve, you would need to embed this hybrid approach into a genuinely new task (e.g. indefinite causal\u2013order routing, higher-order topological invariants, non-Hermitian channel switching, etc.) rather than simple state transfer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for pytheus: implement the minimum \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network\u2010coding primitive by \u201ccross\u2010teleporting\u201d two input qubits at nodes A and C onto outputs B and D simultaneously.  \n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors 0\u20133 as the four logical qubits:  \n  \u2022 0 = A_in  \n  \u2022 1 = C_in  \n  \u2022 2 = B_out  \n  \u2022 3 = D_out  \n\nGoal: Starting from an arbitrary two\u2010qubit input |x\u27e9\u2080|y\u27e9\u2081, the network will deliver |x\u27e9 to output 3 (D_out) and |y\u27e9 to output 2 (B_out) in one static linear-optical circuit.  In the computational basis this defines the 4-qubit \u201cbutterfly\u201d mapping  \n  |00\u27e9\u2192|00\u27e9_out,  |01\u27e9\u2192|10\u27e9_out,  |10\u27e9\u2192|01\u27e9_out,  |11\u27e9\u2192|11\u27e9_out.  \n\nImplementation ingredients:\n  \u2022 Two weak-excitation SPDC sources (S1, S2) each emit a Bell pair: S1 connects modes [0,A\u2032] and S2 connects [1,C\u2032].  \n  \u2022 Two on-demand single-photon emitters (SE1, SE2) generate ancilla photons in modes B\u2032 and D\u2032 to mediate two simultaneous Bell measurements (one on A\u2032\u2013B\u2032, one on C\u2032\u2013D\u2032).  \n  \u2022 A fixed linear-optical network mixes these six modes and routes them into detectors [0,1,2,3] for the logical qubits and four ancilla detectors [4\u20137] for heralding.  \n  \u2022 We forbid any SPDC source to feed directly into the wrong Bell\u2010measurement port (use `removed_connections` to exclude edges S1\u2192D\u2032, S2\u2192B\u2032).  \n  \u2022 Condition on four-fold coincidences in the ancillas: the heralded event completes two teleportations in crossed order, achieving the butterfly map.  \n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Sources:      [S1]   [S2]   [SE1]   [SE2]  \n  Linear optics:[     central interferometer for two Bell projections     ]  \n  Detectors:    [0(A_in)] [1(C_in)] [2(B_out)] [3(D_out)] [4][5][6][7 (ancillas)]  \n\nExample pytheus config snippet:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum butterfly: cross\u2010teleportation network coding\",\n  foldername:         \"butterfly-code\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            4,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  in_nodes:           [0,1],\n  out_nodes:          [2,3],\n  target_quantum:     [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"],\n  single_emitters:    [S1_index, S2_index],     # replace with actual indices for SE1, SE2\n  removed_connections:[\n      [detector_Dprime, source_S1],\n      [detector_Bprime, source_S2]\n  ],\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nThis setup realizes a genuine two\u2010qubit routing primitive\u2014the quantum analogue of the butterfly network\u2014using weak SPDC pairs for input entanglement and strong\u2010coupling emitters for the intermediate Bell measurements.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d cross\u2010teleport network is essentially the same dual\u2013qubit cross\u2010teleportation primitive already proposed in the ensemble (see \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross\u2010Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\u201d).     "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). A hybrid teleportation channel: use two SPDC sources in the weak\u2010excitation regime to perform a Bell\u2010measurement at node A, and use two strongly-coupled single-photon emitters to generate the Bell\u2010pair resource between nodes B and C. Conditioned on the four-photon Bell measurement, an arbitrary qubit at A is teleported to C.\n    2. A repeater\u2010chain entanglement\u2010swapping network: alternate SPDC pair sources (weak excitation) and single-emitter heralded entangling links (strong coupling) to swap entanglement hop-by-hop across a three-node chain, then post-select to entangle the end nodes.\n    3. A three-party coded teleportation/secret-sharing protocol: use SPDC pairs to encode an input qubit into a distributed code across nodes B and C, and single emitters to perform Bell projections for decoding.  \n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus\u2010obstacles:\n    1. The teleportation channel is not on the existing list (only swapping and static state generation were done), and it requires no dynamic feedback\u2014just post-selection\u2014so Pytheus can handle it.  \n    2. The repeater\u2010chain is close to entanglement swapping examples but adds heterogeneous sources; Pytheus can mix SPDC + single_emitters, so it\u2019s feasible but less conceptually distinct.  \n    3. The coded teleportation is essentially GHZ/W\u2010state preparation and falls into state generation, which is forbidden.  \n  Step 3: The most promising is idea 1, the hybrid teleportation channel.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no experiment in the existing list implements full qubit teleportation (a nontrivial network transformation) by mixing SPDC sources (weak excitation) for the Bell unknown qubit at node A (detector 0) to node C (detector 1).  \n\u2013 The Bell measurement at A is implemented by two weak-excitation SPDC pair sources whose photons meet in a small linear-optics network and are post-selected on four ancilla detectors (2,3,4,5).  \n\u2013 The entangled resource between B and C is generated by two on-demand single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter coupling), each feeding into modes that are combined interferometrically before reaching detectors at B\u2019s station and C\u2019s output port.  \n\u2013 We enforce that no SPDC source directly populates C and no single-emitter directly populates A by using `removed_connections`.  \n\u2013 Upon coincidence detection in the four ancilla modes, the state at A is teleported to C.  \n A quantum butterfly (network\u2010coding) protocol: two input qubits at A and C are \u201ccross\u2010teleported\u201d to outputs B and D in one step, using SPDC entangled resources for the inputs and single\u2010emitter photons for the intermediate Bell projections.\n    3. Butterfly network coding is absent from the existing list, is a genuine network transformation, and can be phrased as a 4\u2010qubit \u201ccross\u2010teleportation\u201d target. It uses only SPDC, single_emitters, linear optics, and post\u2010selection\u2014Pytheus compatible.\n    3. Quantum switch is elegant but again ends up as an entangled state generation of control+output\u2014too close to state generation.\n  Step 3: The quantum butterfly network coding primitive (option 2) is most promising: it is a bona\u2010fide network transformation, novel in pytheus, meets all constraints, and combines both regimes.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because pytheus has never tackled a quantum\u2010network\u2010coding task (the \u201cbutterfly\u201d network) and it goes beyond simple swapping or teleportation by delivering two qubits across a cross\u2010connected network in one go.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the pytheus framework because it uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (weak excitation), single\u2010photon emitters (strong coupling), static linear\u2010optical mixing, and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state-generation prescription.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for pytheus: implement the minimum \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network\u2010coding primitive by \u201ccross\u2010teleporting\u201d two input qubits at nodes A and C onto outputs B and D simultaneously.  \n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors 0\u20133 as the four logical qubits:  \n  \u2022 0 = A_in  \n  \u2022 1 = C_in  \n  \u2022 2 = B_out  \n  \u2022 3 = D_out  \n\nGoal: Starting from an arbitrary two\u2010qubit input |x\u27e9\u2080|y\u27e9\u2081, the network will deliver |x\u27e9 to output 3 (D_out) and |y\u27e9 to output 2 (B_out) in one static linear-optical circuit.  In the computational basis this defines the 4-qubit \u201cbutterfly\u201d mapping  \n  |00\u27e9\u2192|00\u27e9_out,  |01\u27e9\u2192|10\u27e9_out,  |10\u27e9\u2192|01\u27e9_out,  |11\u27e9\u2192|11\u27e9_out.  \n\nImplementation ingredients:\n  \u2022 Two weak-excitation SPDC sources (S1, S2) each emit a Bell pair: S1 connects modes [0,A\u2032] and S2 connects [1,C\u2032].  \n  \u2022 Two on-demand single-photon emitters (SE1, SE2) generate ancilla photons in modes B\u2032 and D\u2032 to mediate two simultaneous Bell measurements (one on A\u2032\u2013B\u2032, one on C\u2032\u2013D\u2032).  \n  \u2022 A fixed linear-optical network mixes these six modes and routes them into detectors [0,1,2,3] for the logical qubits and four ancilla detectors [4\u20137] for heralding.  \n  \u2022 We forbid any SPDC source to feed directly into the wrong Bell\u2010measurement port (use `removed_connections` to exclude edges S1\u2192D\u2032, S2\u2192B\u2032).  \n  \u2022 Condition on four-fold coincidences in the ancillas: the heralded event completes two teleportations in crossed order, achieving the butterfly map.  \n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Sources:      [S1]   [S2]   [SE1]   [SE2]  \n  Linear optics:[     central interferometer for two Bell projections     ]  \n  Detectors:    [0(A_in)] [1(C_in)] [2(B_out)] [3(D_out)] [4][5][6][7 (ancillas)]  \n\nExample pytheus config snippet:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum butterfly: cross\u2010teleportation network coding\",\n  foldername:         \"butterfly-code\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            4,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  in_nodes:           [0,1],\n  out_nodes:          [2,3],\n  target_quantum:     [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"],\n  single_emitters:    [S1_index, S2_index],     # control of an on\u2010demand emitter qubit.  \n\u2013 A weak-excitation SPDC pair_source S creates a Bell pair across modes [S1, C].  \n\u2013 A single\u2010photon emitter E prepares the control qubit in a dual\u2010rail superposition across modes [E0, E1].  \n\u2013 A static linear\u2010optical network interferes the SPDC signal mode S1 with the two emitter rails E0/E1.  \n\u2013 Two of the output modes go to detectors A_out (detectors 0,1) and B_out (2,3) in dual rails; node C always holds its SPDC idler (detectors 4,5).  \n\u2013 Two heralding detectors (6,7) signal successful routing.  \nConditioned on a click on {6,7}, the final photonic state across (E, A_out, B_out, C) is\n  |0\u27e9_E \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,C}  +  |1\u27e9_E \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B,C},\ni.e. entanglement between C and A if the emitter was in |0\u27e9, or C and B if in |1\u27e9\u2014in coherent superposition.\n\nVisualization (sources top\u2192bottom):\n  [ S (pair_source) ]   [ E linear-optical router   \u2502  \n circuit.  \n\u2022 Combines weak-excitation SPDC for resource generation with a strong-coupling single emitter for coherent control.  \n\u2022 Can be extended to N-destination routers or cascaded to form reconfigurable quantum repeater networks.  \n\u2022 Purely static linear optics and post\u2010selection; no dynamic feedback or forbidden encodings.  \n\u2022 Opens the door to theory investigations of multiplexer\u2010based entanglement percolation and programmable quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Routing an SPDC link under emitter control has been proposed (e.g. the Pythreus-compatible multiplexed entanglement router and spectral-control router). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine a weak\u2010excitation SPDC source with a strong\u2010coupling single\u2010photon emitter into a Pytheus\u2010compatible network primitive (beyond simple swapping or teleportation):  \n    1. A controlled\u2010basis entanglement\u2010swap where an on\u2010demand emitter qubit coherently selects between two Bell bases for the swap measurement, producing a superposition of swapped\u2010states.  \n    2. A fan\u2010out entanglement distributor that uses an emitter qubit to route half of an SPDC pair among three output nodes in superposition.  \n    3. A two\u2010step fusion\u2010swap: fuse two SPDC pairs into one, then swap with an emitter\u2010generated Bell pair\u2014all in one static circuit.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:  \n    1. Controlled\u2010basis swap is not in the existing list (all swaps use a fixed Bell basis), uses only SPDC + single_emitters + static optics + post\u2010selection, and yields a true network transformation (coherent switching of the swap\u2010basis).  \n    2. Fan\u2010out routing is conceptually similar to earlier routers and likely covered.  \n    3. Fusion\u2010swap collapses to two known primitives (fusion and swap) and feels like state\u2010generation of a four\u2010photon GHZ\u2010type state.  \n  Step 3: The controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (option 1) wins: it\u2019s a fundamental network\u2010measurement primitive that can be generalized to N bases, nodes, and higher\u2010dimensional systems.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no Pytheus experiment so far implements entanglement swapping with a measurement basis under coherent control\u2014every swap in the literature uses a fixed Bell basis.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only (i) one SPDC pair_source and one SPDC idler mode for the two links, (ii) one single_emitter as the control qubit, (iii) a static linear\u2010optical network mixing the two ancilla modes with the control photon to effect a controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement, and (iv) post-selection on two heralding detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a controlled\u2010basis entanglement\u2010swap primitive.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors as follows (dual\u2010rail encodings):\n \u2022 Control qubit (emitter) \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon A_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 2  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon B_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 3  \n \u2022 Idler photons of the two SPDC links are at nodes A (mode 4) and B (mode 5)  \n \u2022 Two ancilla detectors (6,7) herald the Bell\u2010measurement outcome.\n\nGoal:  \nStart with an SPDC\u2010generated Bell pair between modes [2,4] (weak\u2010excitation) and another between [3,5]. A single\u2010photon emitter (strong coupling) prepares control |+\u27e9_c across [0,1]. A static interferometer mixes modes 0\u20133 such that detection in {6,7} implements a Bell measurement on [2,3] in basis  \n  \u201c\u03a6\u00b1\u201d if control = |0\u27e9,  \n  \u201c\u03a8\u00b1\u201d if control = |1\u27e9.  \nConditioning on a particular heralding click yields the final joint state on (control,[4,5]):\n   (|0\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{4,5}  +  |1\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9_{4,5})/\u221a2.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [ SPDC_pair ]   [ single_photon_emitter ]  \n  Linear optics:  \u2500\u2500 central interferometer effecting controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement \u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:    [0][1 (control)] [2][3 (swap inputs)] [4][5 (outputs A,B)] [6][7 (heralds)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ctrl_basis_swap\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [SPDC_index],\n  single_emitters:    [Emitter_index],\n  in_nodes:           [],         # necessary for implementing \u03a8 basis\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2022 It defines a new network primitive: entanglement swapping with a coherently controlled measurement basis, rather than a fixed Bell basis.  \n\u2022 Combines weak\u2010excitation SPDC resources for link pairs with a deterministic emitter qubit control.  \n\u2022 Uses only static linear optics and post\u2010selection\u2014no dynamic feedback or hyper\u2010entanglement.  \n\u2022 Can be extended to multiple bases, higher dimensions, or cascaded to probe adaptive network protocols.  \n\u2022 The theoretical significance lies in exploring the quantum\u2010coherent interplay between choice of network measurement and resulting entanglement\u2014ripe for a theory paper in PRL.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled-basis swap duplicates the ensemble\u2019s telecom-band example of routing between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements via a superposed control photon.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: I will propose a \u201ccontrolled\u2010basis entanglement swap\u201d primitive in which an on\u2010demand emitter qubit coherently selects between two distinct Bell\u2010measurement bases on two SPDC\u2010generated Bell pairs, thus implementing a swap in a superposition of measurement choices\u2014a genuine network transformation rather than mere state generation.\n  Step 2: Novelty & obstacles:\n    \u2022 Nothing in the existing Pytheus library implements a Bell\u2010swap whose measurement basis is placed in quantum superposition. All prior swaps use a fixed basis.  \n    \u2022 Pytheus can handle SPDC pair sources, single_photon_emitters, a static linear\u2010optical network, and post\u2010selection. There is no need for feedback control or forbidden encodings.\n  Step 3: This is the most promising: it is a new three\u2010qubit network operation (control + swap inputs \u2192 swapped outputs) that directly combines weak\u2010excitation SPDC and strong\u2010coupling emitters.\n  Step 4: Novel because no previous design lets a control photon choose the swap basis in superposition\u2014opening the door to coherent programmability of network measurements.  \n  Step 5: Feasible in Pytheus: specify one SPDC pair_source, one single_emitter as the control qubit, a static interferometer mixing the two link photons and the control rails, two heralding detectors, and the final 3-qubit target over control + output rails.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExplanation:\nWe have two SPDC pair sources each creating a Bell pair on modes (A1, A2) and (B1, B2). A single\u2010photon emitter prepares the control qubit |+\u27e9_c in dual\u2010rail modes (C0,C1). A static linear\u2010optical network mixes (A2,B1,C0,C1) so that upon clicks on two herald detectors (modes H0,H1) we have performed:\n  \u2013 a \u03a6\u00b1-basis Bell measurement on (A2,B1) if the control rail C0 clicks,  \n  \u2013 a \u03a8\u00b1-basis Bell measurement on (A2,B1) if the control rail C1 clicks.  \nConditioned on a particular heralding outcome, A1 and B2 end up swapped into either \u03a6+ (control=|0\u27e9) or \u03a8+ (control=|1\u27e9). The final three\u2010qubit state on (control, A1, B2) is\n  (|0\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a6+\u27e9_{A1,B2}  +  |1\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a8+\u27e9_{A1,B2})/\u221a2.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [SPDC1]   [SPDC2]   [Emitter_C]  \n  Interferometer:  \u2500\u2500 central optics implementing controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement \u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:    [0(C0)] [1(C1)] [2(A1)] [3(B2)] [4(H0)] [5(H1)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ctrl_basis_swap\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [0,1],            # indices for SPDC1, SPDC2\n  single_emitters:    [2],              # index for Emitter_C\n  in_nodes:           [],               # no external inputs\u2014resources come from sources\n  out_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],        # C0,C1 (control rails) & A1,B2 (swap outputs)\n  target_quantum:     [\n    \"100011\",  # |0>_c \u2297 |\u03a6+>_{A1,B2}: C0=1,C1=0,A1=0,B2=0\n    \"101100\",  #           \u2026               A1=1,B2=1\n    \"010101\",  # |1>_c \u2297 |\u03a8+>_{A1,B2}: C0=0,C1=1,A1=0,B2=1\n    \"011010\"   #           \u2026               A1=1,B2=0\n  ],\n  removed_connections: [\n    # prevent SPDC2 idler (mode B2) leaking into the control rails\n    [0,1],[1,1],\n    # prevent control rails feeding directly into the swap outputs\n    [2,2],[3,2]\n  ],\n  imaginary:          true,     # needed to distinguish \u03a6 vs \u03a8 phases\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2022 It realizes a new network primitive: entanglement\u2010swap whose measurement basis is quantum\u2010controlled.  \n\u2022 Merges weak\u2010excitation SPDC resources for the link photons with a strong\u2010coupling emitter for coherent control.  \n\u2022 Uses only static linear optics and post\u2010selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n\u2022 Can be extended to multiple bases, higher dimensions, or cascaded to build programmable measurement networks.  \n\u2022 Opens theory questions about the resource cost of programmable network measurements and their role in adaptive communication protocols."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Three-Node Linear-Optical Violation of the Bilocality Inequality\n\nAbstract: We propose a bilocality-test network in which two independent probabilistic entangled-photon-pair sources feed a static partial Bell-state analyzer at a central node B, while peripheral nodes A and C perform fixed-basis single-qubit measurements conditioned on ancilla-heralded joint outcomes at B. The experiment explicitly targets the conditional A\u2013C correlations\u2014tagged by B\u2019s heralding pattern\u2014to achieve a maximal violation of the bilocality inequality, thereby demonstrating genuine non-bilocal quantum correlations beyond standard two-party Bell tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Photonic Magic-Square Contextuality Test via Overlapping Bell-Fusions\n\nMini-abstract: We propose an integrated eight-photon experiment on a nanoscale waveguide circuit that implements the Peres\u2013Mermin magic square through four overlapping linear-optics Bell-fusion measurements arranged in a square topology, with enforced adjacency constraints to reveal true contextuality. By post-selecting the four target 8-bit click patterns 11001100, 00110011, 10101010, and 01010101\u2014which satisfy the square\u2019s row/column parity constraints\u2014this scheme directly tests a commuting-observables contextuality scenario inaccessible to concatenated Bell analyses.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Z\u2083 Topological Teleportation of a Qutrit via Triple-Path Superposition\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate an all-linear-optical protocol that teleports an arbitrary input qutrit |\u03c8\u27e9 from source node S to the target qutrit at node T by coherently superposing three disjoint Bell-swap entanglement paths through intermediate nodes A, B, and C.  Post-selected detection of one photon per ancilla and one click at T heralds a U_Z\u2083 phase imprint diag(1,e^{2\u03c0i/3},e^{4\u03c0i/3}) on the teleported qutrit basis {\u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9,\u22232\u27e9}, directly encoding the network\u2019s Z\u2083 loop homology class as a genuine higher-order topological invariant of the teleportation channel.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. This heralded W-state projection primitive enables satellite-relayed free-space conference QKD by distributing and measuring genuine three-party W-state correlations for secure conference-key distillation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. By combining two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a single-photon input qubit and a control ancilla in a fixed linear-optical interferometer, we perform Bell-state measurements and post-select on \u201c+\u201d outcomes to herald a coherent superposition of the ES\u2192QT and QT\u2192ES sequences, all without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nTeleportation-Based Detection of Flat-Band Topology in a Photonic Creutz Ladder  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a PyTheus-compatible entanglement-swapping protocol on a two-leg photonic Creutz ladder with tunable imaginary diagonal couplings to realize topologically trivial and nontrivial regimes. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a concrete proposal for Pytheus to design a hybrid-regime teleportation network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to teleport an unknown qubit at node A (detector 0) to node C (detector 1).  \n\u2013 The Bell measurement at A is implemented by two weak-excitation SPDC pair sources whose photons meet in a small linear-optics network and are post-selected on four ancilla detectors (2,3,4,5).  \n\u2013 The entangled resource between B and C is generated by two on-demand single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter coupling), each feeding into modes that are combined interferometrically before reaching detectors at B\u2019s station and C\u2019s output port.  \n\u2013 We enforce that no SPDC source directly populates C and no single-emitter directly populates A by using `removed_connections`.  \n\u2013 Upon coincidence detection in the four ancilla modes, the state at A is teleported to C.  \n  \nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n  emitters/sources: [SPDC1][SPDC2]   [SE1][SE2]  \n  interferometer :   [  Bell-meas unit  ]   [  resource-prep unit ]  \n  detectors       : [0 (A)] [1 (C)] [2][3][4][5 (ancillas)]  \n  \nConfig for Pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Hybrid teleportation: SPDC Bell-measurement + single-emitter entangled resource\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid-teleport\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 15,\n  in_nodes: [0],\n  out_nodes: [1],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\", \"11\"],\n  single_emitters: [2, 3],           # sources false\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a standard quantum\u2010teleportation circuit, merely substituting two SPDC sources for the Bell measurement and two on-demand emitters for the entangled pair. Teleportation itself is far from novel (and many hybrid light\u2013matter teleportation experiments have already been studied), so this target does not introduce a new network primitive or fundamentally new effect beyond what is in the literature.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Teleportation alone\u2014even using mixed SPDC and single-emitter resources\u2014is not sufficiently novel for a PRL-level network primitive. To improve, you would need to embed this hybrid approach into a genuinely new task (e.g. indefinite causal\u2013order routing, higher-order topological invariants, non-Hermitian channel switching, etc.) rather than simple state transfer.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for pytheus: implement the minimum \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network\u2010coding primitive by \u201ccross\u2010teleporting\u201d two input qubits at nodes A and C onto outputs B and D simultaneously.  \n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors 0\u20133 as the four logical qubits:  \n  \u2022 0 = A_in  \n  \u2022 1 = C_in  \n  \u2022 2 = B_out  \n  \u2022 3 = D_out  \n\nGoal: Starting from an arbitrary two\u2010qubit input |x\u27e9\u2080|y\u27e9\u2081, the network will deliver |x\u27e9 to output 3 (D_out) and |y\u27e9 to output 2 (B_out) in one static linear-optical circuit.  In the computational basis this defines the 4-qubit \u201cbutterfly\u201d mapping  \n  |00\u27e9\u2192|00\u27e9_out,  |01\u27e9\u2192|10\u27e9_out,  |10\u27e9\u2192|01\u27e9_out,  |11\u27e9\u2192|11\u27e9_out.  \n\nImplementation ingredients:\n  \u2022 Two weak-excitation SPDC sources (S1, S2) each emit a Bell pair: S1 connects modes [0,A\u2032] and S2 connects [1,C\u2032].  \n  \u2022 Two on-demand single-photon emitters (SE1, SE2) generate ancilla photons in modes B\u2032 and D\u2032 to mediate two simultaneous Bell measurements (one on A\u2032\u2013B\u2032, one on C\u2032\u2013D\u2032).  \n  \u2022 A fixed linear-optical network mixes these six modes and routes them into detectors [0,1,2,3] for the logical qubits and four ancilla detectors [4\u20137] for heralding.  \n  \u2022 We forbid any SPDC source to feed directly into the wrong Bell\u2010measurement port (use `removed_connections` to exclude edges S1\u2192D\u2032, S2\u2192B\u2032).  \n  \u2022 Condition on four-fold coincidences in the ancillas: the heralded event completes two teleportations in crossed order, achieving the butterfly map.  \n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Sources:      [S1]   [S2]   [SE1]   [SE2]  \n  Linear optics:[     central interferometer for two Bell projections     ]  \n  Detectors:    [0(A_in)] [1(C_in)] [2(B_out)] [3(D_out)] [4][5][6][7 (ancillas)]  \n\nExample pytheus config snippet:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum butterfly: cross\u2010teleportation network coding\",\n  foldername:         \"butterfly-code\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            4,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  in_nodes:           [0,1],\n  out_nodes:          [2,3],\n  target_quantum:     [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"],\n  single_emitters:    [S1_index, S2_index],     # replace with actual indices for SE1, SE2\n  removed_connections:[\n      [detector_Dprime, source_S1],\n      [detector_Bprime, source_S2]\n  ],\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nThis setup realizes a genuine two\u2010qubit routing primitive\u2014the quantum analogue of the butterfly network\u2014using weak SPDC pairs for input entanglement and strong\u2010coupling emitters for the intermediate Bell measurements.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d cross\u2010teleport network is essentially the same dual\u2013qubit cross\u2010teleportation primitive already proposed in the ensemble (see \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross\u2010Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\u201d). It offers no new fundamental task or resource advantage beyond that prior suggestion.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The cross\u2010teleportation butterfly routing of two inputs to two outputs has already been covered (e.g. the SiV\u2010based butterfly proposal). To be novel you must propose a genuinely new network primitive or functionality\u2014not just another incarnation of cross\u2010teleportation with different hardware.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus: design a post-selected Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate that melds weak-excitation SPDC sources and on-demand single-photon emitters.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label six photons as follows:\n \u2022 Control qubit: emitted by a single-photon emitter SE_C in dual-rail modes C0/C1 \u2192 detectors [0,1].\n \u2022 Target qubits T1 & T2: each encoded in one photon from two SPDC pair sources S1 and S2 in dual-rail (modes T10/T11 and T20/T21) \u2192 detectors [2,3] and [4,5].\n \u2022 Two additional SPDC pair sources A1, A2 supply four ancilla photons for heralding.\n\nGoal:  \nImplement the unitary\n  |c\u27e9|t1\u27e9|t2\u27e9 \u2192 |c\u27e9 (if c=0: |t1\u27e9|t2\u27e9 ; if c=1: |t2\u27e9|t1\u27e9 ).\n  \nAll optics are static: linear interferometers mix the six data modes plus four ancilla modes; number-resolving detectors herald the successful Fredkin action.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [SE_C]   [S1]   [S2]   [A1]   [A2]  \n  Linear optics:[   central interferometer implementing controlled-SWAP via post-selection  ]  \n  Detectors:    [0(C0)] [1(C1)] [2(T10)] [3(T11)] [4(T20)] [5(T21)] [6][7][8][9 (ancillas)]\n\nKey Pytheus keywords:\n \u2022 single_emitters: [SE_C_index]  \n \u2022 probabilistic pair_sources: [S1, S2, A1, A2]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 4 (ancilla detectors 6\u20139)  \n \u2022 in_nodes: [0,1,2,3,4,5]       (dual-rail for control + targets)  \n \u2022 out_nodes: [0,1,2,3,4,5]      (same rails after gate)  \n \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any direct path from S1 or S2 into the ancilla network for the control, e.g. [[0,S1],[1,S1],[0,S2],[1,S2]] to ensure no \u201cwhich-path\u201d leakage.  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a list of all eight basis mappings  \n     [\"000000\",\"001001\",\"010010\",\"011011\",\"100000\",\"101100\",\"110011\",\"111111\"]  \n   (Dual-rail ordering: C0,C1,T10,T11,T20,T21 \u2014 input \u2192 output.)\n\nExample config sketch:\n{\n A coincidence click on {2,3} heralds a successful swap, projecting detectors 0 and 1 onto a Bell\u2010state.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:         [ S (pair_source) ]   [ E1 ]   [ E2 ]  \n  Linear interferometer:  \u2500\u2500\u2500 central mixing for Bell\u2010state preparation (E1&E2) and Bell\u2010measurement (X,Y) \u2500\u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:       [0 (A_out)] [1 (D_out)] [2][3 (herald)]  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Hybrid entanglement swapping: SPDC + single emitters\",\n  foldername:         \"hybrid_swap_link\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            15,\n  pair_sources:       [S_index],\n  single_emitters:    [E1_index, E2_index],\n  in_nodes:           [0,1],      # A_out, D_out\n  out_nodes:          [0,1],\n  target_quantum:     [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  removed_connections:[\n    # forbid any SPDC\u2192D or emitter\u2192A direct links\n    [1, S_index], [0, E1_index], [0, E2_index]\n  ],\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2013 It\u2019s a true entanglement\u2010swapping network operation (no unreachable \u201cstate generation\u201d).  \n\u2013 It trades one full probabilistic SPDC pair for a pair distilled from two deterministic emitters, cutting the heralding/ancilla overhead in half.  \n\u2013 By varying the mix (e.g. replacing k SPDC links by 2k emitters), one can explore the performance frontier of quantum repeater links as a function of resource determinism\u2014ripe for a theory paper and follow-on experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed hybrid entanglement swap simply replaces one SPDC link with a Bell pair generated by two single\u2010photon emitters and performs a standard Bell measurement to swap entanglement. Two SPDC pair_sources generate Bell\u2010pairs on links A\u2013B and B\u2013C; a single\u2010photon emitter prepares the control qubit |+\u27e9_c. A static linear\u2010optical network routes the Bell\u2010measurements in two orders conditioned on the control path, and two heralding detectors signal success. The final joint state of (control, A_out, C_out) is\n   (|0\u27e9_c \u2297 |\u03a6+\u27e9_{A,C} + |1\u27e9_c \u2297 |\u03a6\u2212\u27e9_{A,C})/\u221a2.\nThis realizes indefinite causal order of two entanglement swaps in one post\u2010selected circuit, combining weak\u2010excitation SPDC and strong\u2010coupling emitters without dynamic control.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:          [SPDC1]   [SPDC2]   [Emitter_C]  \n  Linear optics:    [    central interferometer implementing controlled\u2010order swapping & Bell\u2010measurement    ]  \n  Detectors:        [0(C0)] [1(C1)] [2(A_out0)] [3(A_out1)] [4(C_out0)] [5(C_out1)] [6,7 (heralds)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum switch: superposed\u2010order entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ent_swap_switch\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [S1_index, S2_index],\n  single_emitters:    [C_index],\n  in_nodes:           [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  out_nodes:          [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  target_quantum:     [ \n                       \"000000\",  # |0\u27e9_c |00\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"011011\",  # |0\u27e9_c |11\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"100000\",  # |1\u27e9_c |00\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"-111011\"  # - or coupling causal superposition to another nonclassical resource) rather than simply restating the switch in hybrid hardware.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a concrete Pytheus target: a quantum entanglement router that uses an on\u2010demand emitter qubit to steer one photon of an SPDC Bell pair to one of two recipients in superposition.\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to distribute entanglement between a fixed node C and either node A or node B, under the control of an on\u2010demand emitter qubit.  \n\u2013 A weak-excitation SPDC pair_source S creates a Bell pair across modes [S1, C].  \n\u2013 A single\u2010photon emitter E prepares the control qubit in a dual\u2010rail superposition across modes [E0, E1].  \n\u2013 A static linear\u2010optical network interferes the SPDC signal mode S1 with the two emitter rails E0/E1.  \n\u2013 Two of the output modes go to detectors A_out (detectors 0,1) and B_out (2,3) in dual rails; node C always holds its SPDC idler (detectors 4,5).  \n\u2013 Two heralding detectors (6,7) signal successful routing.  \nConditioned on a click on {6,7}, the final photonic state across (E, A_out, B_out, C) is\n  |0\u27e9_E \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,C}  +  |1\u27e9_E \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B,C},\ni.e. entanglement between C and A if the emitter was in |0\u27e9, or C and B if in |1\u27e9\u2014in coherent superposition.\n\nVisualization (sources top\u2192bottom):\n  [ S (pair_source) ]   [ E (single_emitter) ]  \n         \u2193                     \u2193  \n necessary for implementing \u03a8 basis\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2022 It defines a new network primitive: entanglement swapping with a coherently controlled measurement basis, rather than a fixed Bell basis.  \n\u2022 Combines weak\u2010excitation SPDC resources for link pairs with a deterministic emitter qubit control.  \n\u2022 Uses only static linear optics and post\u2010selection\u2014no dynamic feedback or hyper\u2010entanglement.  \n\u2022 Can be extended to multiple bases, higher dimensions, or cascaded to probe adaptive network protocols.  \n\u2022 The theoretical significance lies in exploring the quantum\u2010coherent interplay between choice of network measurement and resulting entanglement\u2014ripe for a theory paper in PRL.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal to coherently control the Bell\u2010measurement basis during entanglement swapping via an emitter qubit is essentially the same network primitive as the \u201cQuantum\u2010Controlled Time\u2010Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band\u201d already in the ensemble. It neither introduces a new task nor a fundamentally different resource trade-off beyond that prior suggestion.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This controlled-basis swap duplicates the ensemble\u2019s telecom-band example of routing between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements via a superposed control photon. A single\u2010photon emitter prepares the control qubit |+\u27e9_c in dual\u2010rail modes (C0,C1). A static linear\u2010optical network mixes (A2,B1,C0,C1) so that upon clicks on two herald detectors (modes H0,H1) we have performed:\n  \u2013 a \u03a6\u00b1-basis Bell measurement on (A2,B1) if the control rail C0 clicks,  \n  \u2013 a \u03a8\u00b1-basis Bell measurement on (A2,B1) if the control rail C1 clicks.  \nConditioned on a particular heralding outcome, A1 and B2 end up swapped into either \u03a6+ (control=|0\u27e9) or \u03a8+ (control=|1\u27e9). The final three\u2010qubit state on (control, A1, B2) is\n  (|0\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a6+\u27e9_{A1,B2}  +  |1\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a8+\u27e9_{A1,B2})/\u221a2.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [SPDC1]   [SPDC2]   [Emitter_C]  \n  Interferometer:  \u2500\u2500 central optics implementing controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement \u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:    [0(C0)] [1(C1)] [2(A1)] [3(B2)] [4(H0)] [5(H1)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ctrl_basis_swap\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [0,1],            #     "output": "Thought: The proposal for a control-basis entanglement swap\u2014where an emitter qubit coherently selects between \u03a6- and \u03a8-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC links\u2014is essentially the same network primitive already covered by the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum-Controlled Time-Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band.\u201d It does not introduce a new higher-order functionality or resource advantage beyond that earlier suggestion.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This controlled-basis swap duplicates the ensemble\u2019s prior controlled-measurement swapping example. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. Conditioned on the four-photon Bell measurement, an arbitrary qubit at A is teleported to C.\n    2. A repeater\u2010chain entanglement\u2010swapping network: alternate SPDC pair sources (weak excitation) and single-emitter heralded entangling links (strong coupling) to swap entanglement hop-by-hop across a three-node chain, then post-select to entangle the end nodes.\n    3. A three-party coded teleportation/secret-sharing protocol: use SPDC pairs to encode an input qubit into a distributed code across nodes B and C, and single emitters to perform Bell projections for decoding.  \n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus\u2010obstacles:\n    1. The teleportation channel is not on the existing list (only swapping and static state generation were done), and it requires no dynamic feedback\u2014just post-selection\u2014so Pytheus can handle it.  \n    2. The repeater\u2010chain is close to entanglement swapping examples but adds heterogeneous sources; Pytheus can mix SPDC + single_emitters, so it\u2019s feasible but less conceptually distinct.  \n    3. The coded teleportation is essentially GHZ/W\u2010state preparation and falls into state generation, which is forbidden.  \n  Step 3: The most promising is idea 1, the hybrid teleportation channel.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no experiment in the existing list implements full qubit teleportation (a nontrivial network transformation) by mixing SPDC sources (weak excitation) for the Bell measurement with single-photon emitters (strong coupling) for the entangled resource.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only static SPDC pair sources, single_emitters, linear interferometers, and post-selection\u2014no dynamic control, no cavities, and it defines an abstract qubit teleportation target (|0\u27e9\u2192|0\u27e9 + |1\u27e9\u2192|1\u27e9).  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a concrete proposal for Pytheus to design a hybrid-regime teleportation network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to teleport an unknown qubit at node A (detector 0) to node C (detector 1).  \n\u2013 The Bell measurement at A is implemented by two weak-excitation SPDC pair sources whose photons meet in a small linear-optics network and are post-selected on four ancilla detectors (2,3,4,5).  \n\u2013 The entangled resource between B and C is generated by two on-demand single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter coupling), each feeding into modes that are combined interferometrically before reaching detectors at B\u2019s station and C\u2019s output port.  \n\u2013 We enforce that no SPDC source directly populates C and no single-emitter directly populates A by using `removed_connections`.  \n\u2013 Upon coincidence detection in the four ancilla modes, the state at A is teleported to C.  \n Two SPDC pair_sources generate Bell\u2010pairs on links A\u2013B and B\u2013C; a single\u2010photon emitter prepares the control qubit |+\u27e9_c. A static linear\u2010optical network routes the Bell\u2010measurements in two orders conditioned on the control path, and two heralding detectors signal success. The final joint state of (control, A_out, C_out) is\n   (|0\u27e9_c \u2297 |\u03a6+\u27e9_{A,C} + |1\u27e9_c \u2297 |\u03a6\u2212\u27e9_{A,C})/\u221a2.\nThis realizes indefinite causal order of two entanglement swaps in one post\u2010selected circuit, combining weak\u2010excitation SPDC and strong\u2010coupling emitters without dynamic control.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:          [SPDC1]   [SPDC2]   [Emitter_C]  \n  Linear optics:    [    central interferometer implementing controlled\u2010order swapping & Bell\u2010measurement    ]  \n  Detectors:        [0(C0)] [1(C1)] [2(A_out0)] [3(A_out1)] [4(C_out0)] [5(C_out1)] [6,7 (heralds)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum switch: superposed\u2010order entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ent_swap_switch\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [S1_index, S2_index],\n  single_emitters:    [C_index],\n  in_nodes:           [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  out_nodes:          [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  target_quantum:     [ \n                       \"000000\",  # |0\u27e9_c |00\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"011011\",  # |0\u27e9_c |11\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"100000\",  # |1\u27e9_c |00\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"-111011\"  # - |1\u27e9_c |11\u27e9_{A,C}\n                     ],\n  removed_connections: [\n    # forbid SPDC1\u2192C_out and SPDC2\u2192A_out to enforce the two\u2010hop structure\n    [4, S1_index], [5, S1_index],\n    [2, S2_index], [3, S2_index]\n  ],\n  imaginary:          true,\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel and feasible:\n\u2022 Novelty: No current Pytheus design implements entanglement\u2010swapping in a superposition of orders\u2014a minimal photonic quantum switch for network links.  \n\u2022 Feasibility: Uses only pair_sources (weak\u2010excitation), single_emitters (strong coupling), static linear optics, and post\u2010selection. No dynamic feedback or forbidden state creation is required.  \n\u2022 Generalizable: By adding more links and control qubits, one can study higher\u2010order causal superpositions and resource trade\u2010offs in repeater networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The indefinite\u2010order entanglement swap has already been proposed in the ensemble. To achieve PRL-worthy novelty, your scheme must embed this switch into a new higher-order protocol (e.g. chaining switches into a network bottleneck, exploiting the control qubit in a nonlocal game, or coupling causal superposition to another nonclassical resource) rather than simply restating the switch in hybrid hardware.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! A hybrid \u201cquantum router\u201d that uses an on-demand emitter qubit to steer one photon of an SPDC Bell pair to one of two output nodes, thereby routing entanglement in superposition.\n    2. A \u201ccontrolled-teleportation\u201d gate: a single-emitter control photon switches between direct transmission and SPDC-based teleportation of an input photon.\n    3. A heralded \u201centanglement purification\u201d primitive: two SPDC-generated noisy pairs are locally purified using two single-emitter ancilla photons plus linear optics and post-selection.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    1. The entanglement-router is new in the pytheus repertoire (no existing \u201crouting\u201d primitive), uses exactly static SPDC sources + single_emitters + linear optics + heralding, and is a genuine network transformation.\n    2. Controlled-teleportation collapses to a conditional SWAP/teleport gate\u2014not as clean or general as router.\n    3. Purification requires modelling noise and multi-round protocols\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s pure-state framework.\n  Step 3: The \u201cquantum entanglement router\u201d is the best: it directly addresses network coding, generalizes to N-destination routing, and cleanly combines weak and strong regimes.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no pytheus experiment so far implements a coherent routing of an SPDC-generated entangled photon by an on-demand emitter qubit\u2014i.e. a true \u201centanglement multiplexer\u201d primitive.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in pytheus because it only needs:\n    \u2022 One SPDC pair_source in the weak-excitation regime  \n    \u2022 One single_photon emitter as the control qubit (strong light\u2013matter coupling)  \n    \u2022 A static linear-optical network mixing three photonic modes (SPDC signal + two rails for the emitter)  \n    \u2022 Four detectors for post-selection (two output nodes + two heralds)  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback and no forbidden hyper-entanglement  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a concrete Pytheus target: a quantum entanglement router that uses an on\u2010demand emitter qubit to steer one photon of an SPDC Bell pair to one of two recipients in superposition.\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to distribute entanglement between a fixed node C and either node A or node B, under the control of an on\u2010demand emitter qubit.  \n\u2013 A weak-excitation SPDC pair_source S creates a Bell pair across modes [S1, C].  \n\u2013 A single\u2010photon emitter E prepares the control qubit in a dual\u2010rail superposition across modes [E0, E1].  \n\u2013 A static linear\u2010optical network interferes the SPDC signal mode S1 with the two emitter rails E0/E1.  \n\u2013 Two of the output modes go to detectors A_out (detectors 0,1) and B_out (2,3) in dual rails; node C always holds its SPDC idler (detectors 4,5).  \n\u2013 Two heralding detectors (6,7) signal successful routing. A controlled\u2010basis entanglement\u2010swap where an on\u2010demand emitter qubit coherently selects between two Bell bases for the swap measurement, producing a superposition of swapped\u2010states.  \n    2. A fan\u2010out entanglement distributor that uses an emitter qubit to route half of an SPDC pair among three output nodes in superposition.  \n    3. A two\u2010step fusion\u2010swap: fuse two SPDC pairs into one, then swap with an emitter\u2010generated Bell pair\u2014all in one static circuit.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:  \n    1. Controlled\u2010basis swap is not in the existing list (all swaps use a fixed Bell basis), uses only SPDC + single_emitters + static optics + post\u2010selection, and yields a true network transformation (coherent switching of the swap\u2010basis).  \n    2. Fan\u2010out routing is conceptually similar to earlier routers and likely covered.  \n    3. Fusion\u2010swap collapses to two known primitives (fusion and swap) and feels like state\u2010generation of a four\u2010photon GHZ\u2010type state.  \n  Step 3: The controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (option 1) wins: it\u2019s a fundamental network\u2010measurement primitive that can be generalized to N bases, nodes, and higher\u2010dimensional systems.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no Pytheus experiment so far implements entanglement swapping with a measurement basis under coherent control\u2014every swap in the literature uses a fixed Bell basis.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only (i) one SPDC pair_source and one SPDC idler mode for the two links, (ii) one single_emitter as the control qubit, (iii) a static linear\u2010optical network mixing the two ancilla modes with the control photon to effect a controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement, and (iv) post-selection on two heralding detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a controlled\u2010basis entanglement\u2010swap primitive.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors as follows (dual\u2010rail encodings):\n \u2022 Control qubit (emitter) \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon A_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 2  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon B_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 3  \n \u2022 Idler photons of the two SPDC links are at nodes A (mode 4) and B (mode 5)  \n \u2022 Two ancilla detectors (6,7) herald the Bell\u2010measurement outcome.\n\nGoal:  \nStart with an SPDC\u2010generated Bell pair between modes [2,4] (weak\u2010excitation) and another between [3,5]. A single\u2010photon emitter (strong coupling) prepares control |+\u27e9_c across [0,1]. A static interferometer mixes modes 0\u20133 such that detection in {6,7} implements a Bell measurement on [2,3] in basis  \n  \u201c\u03a6\u00b1\u201d if control = |0\u27e9,  \n  \u201c\u03a8\u00b1\u201d if control = |1\u27e9.  \nConditioning on a particular heralding click yields the final joint state on (control,[4,5]):\n   (|0\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{4,5}  +  |1\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9_{4,5})/\u221a2.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [ SPDC_pair ]   [ single_photon_emitter ]  \n  Linear optics:  \u2500\u2500 central interferometer effecting controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement \u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:    [0][1 (control)] [2][3 (swap inputs)] [4][5 (outputs A,B)] [6][7 (heralds)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ctrl_basis_swap\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [SPDC_index],\n  single_emitters:    [Emitter_index],\n  in_nodes:           [],         #
