    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Three-Node Linear-Optical Violation of the Bilocality Inequality\n\nAbstract: We propose a bilocality-test network in which two independent probabilistic entangled-photon-pair sources feed a static partial Bell-state analyzer at a central node B, while peripheral nodes A and C perform fixed-basis single-qubit measurements conditioned on ancilla-heralded joint outcomes at B. The experiment explicitly targets the conditional A\u2013C correlations\u2014tagged by B\u2019s heralding pattern\u2014to achieve a maximal violation of the bilocality inequality, thereby demonstrating genuine non-bilocal quantum correlations beyond standard two-party Bell tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. The target is the four-outcome POVM specified by the Bell basis {\u2502\u03a6\u207a\u27e9,\u2502\u03a6\u207b\u27e9,\u2502\u03a8\u207a\u27e9,\u2502\u03a8\u207b\u27e9}, and our algorithm maximizes the conditional probability of correctly identifying each Bell state beyond the 50% bound of passive optics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. Researcher: Here is a concrete proposal for Pytheus to design a hybrid-regime teleportation network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to teleport an unknown qubit at node A (detector 0) to node C (detector 1).  \n\u2013 The Bell measurement at A is implemented by two weak-excitation SPDC pair sources whose photons meet in a small linear-optics network and are post-selected on four ancilla detectors (2,3,4,5).  \n\u2013 The entangled resource between B and C is generated by two on-demand single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter coupling), each feeding into modes that are combined interferometrically before reaching detectors at B\u2019s station and C\u2019s output port.  \n\u2013 We enforce that no SPDC source directly populates C and no single-emitter directly populates A by using `removed_connections`.  \n\u2013 Upon coincidence detection in the four ancilla modes, the state at A is teleported to C.  \n  \nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n  emitters/sources: In the computational basis this defines the 4-qubit \u201cbutterfly\u201d mapping  \n  |00\u27e9\u2192|00\u27e9_out,  |01\u27e9\u2192|10\u27e9_out,  |10\u27e9\u2192|01\u27e9_out,  |11\u27e9\u2192|11\u27e9_out.  \n\nImplementation ingredients:\n  \u2022 Two weak-excitation SPDC sources (S1, S2) each emit a Bell pair: S1 connects modes [0,A\u2032] and S2 connects [1,C\u2032].  \n  \u2022 Two on-demand single-photon emitters (SE1, SE2) generate ancilla photons in modes B\u2032 and D\u2032 to mediate two simultaneous Bell measurements (one on A\u2032\u2013B\u2032, one on C\u2032\u2013D\u2032).  \n  \u2022 A fixed linear-optical network mixes these six modes and routes them into detectors [0,1,2,3] for the logical qubits and four ancilla detectors [4\u20137] for heralding.  \n  \u2022 We forbid any SPDC source to feed directly into the wrong Bell\u2010measurement port (use `removed_connections` to exclude edges S1\u2192D\u2032, S2\u2192B\u2032).  \n  \u2022 Condition on four-fold coincidences in the ancillas: the heralded event completes two teleportations in crossed order, achieving the butterfly map.  \n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Sources:      [S1]   [S2]   [SE1]   [SE2]  \n  Linear optics:[     central interferometer for two Bell projections     ]  \n  Detectors:    [0(A_in)] [1(C_in)] [2(B_out)] [3(D_out)] [4][5][6][7 (ancillas)]  \n\nExample pytheus config snippet:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum butterfly: cross\u2010teleportation network coding\",\n  foldername:         \"butterfly-code\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            4,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  in_nodes:           [0,1],\n  out_nodes:          [2,3],\n  target_quantum:     [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"],\n  single_emitters:    [S1_index, S2_index],     #     "output": "Thought: This controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap is functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum\u2010Controlled Time\u2010Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band,\u201d where a flying qubit coherently selects the Bell\u2010measurement basis. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. A controlled\u2010swap of entanglement: a qubit from a single\u2010emitter control decides whether two SPDC\u2010produced Bell pairs are swapped or left alone, creating a coherent superposition of two network topologies.\n    2. A quantum butterfly (network\u2010coding) protocol: two input qubits at A and C are \u201ccross\u2010teleported\u201d to outputs B and D in one step, using SPDC entangled resources for the inputs and single\u2010emitter photons for the intermediate Bell projections.\n    3. An indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swapping (\u201cquantum switch\u201d) of two hops: an SPDC\u2010based A\u2192B link and a B\u2192C link are applied in a superposition of orders, with a single\u2010emitter control qubit routing the two Bell\u2010measurements.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. A \u201ccontrolled-teleportation\u201d gate: a single-emitter control photon switches between direct transmission and SPDC-based teleportation of an input photon.\n    3. addresses network coding, generalizes to N-destination routing, and cleanly combines weak and strong regimes.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no pytheus experiment so far implements a coherent routing of an SPDC-generated entangled photon by an on-demand emitter qubit\u2014i.e. a true \u201centanglement multiplexer\u201d primitive.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in pytheus because it only control of an on\u2010demand emitter qubit.  \n\u2013 A weak-excitation SPDC pair_source S creates a Bell pair across modes [S1, C].  \n\u2013 A single\u2010photon emitter E prepares the control qubit in a dual\u2010rail superposition across modes [E0, E1].  \n\u2013 A static linear\u2010optical network interferes the SPDC signal mode S1 with the two emitter rails E0/E1.  \n\u2013 Two of the output modes go to detectors A_out (detectors 0,1) and B_out (2,3) in dual rails; node C always holds its SPDC idler (detectors 4,5).  \n\u2013 Two heralding detectors (6,7) signal successful routing. A controlled\u2010basis entanglement\u2010swap where an on\u2010demand emitter qubit coherently selects between two Bell bases for the swap measurement, producing a superposition of swapped\u2010states.  \n    2. A fan\u2010out entanglement distributor that uses an emitter qubit to route half of an SPDC pair among three output nodes in superposition.  \n    3. A two\u2010step fusion\u2010swap: fuse two SPDC pairs into one, then swap with an emitter\u2010generated Bell pair\u2014all in one static circuit.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:  \n    1. Controlled\u2010basis swap is not in the existing list (all swaps use a fixed Bell basis), uses only SPDC + single_emitters + static optics + post\u2010selection, and yields a true network transformation (coherent switching of the swap\u2010basis).  \n    2. Fan\u2010out routing is conceptually similar to earlier routers and likely covered.  \n    3. Fusion\u2010swap collapses to two known primitives (fusion and swap) and feels like state\u2010generation of a four\u2010photon GHZ\u2010type state.  \n  Step 3: The controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (option 1) wins: it\u2019s a fundamental network\u2010measurement primitive that can be generalized to N bases, nodes, and higher\u2010dimensional systems.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no Pytheus experiment so far implements entanglement swapping with a measurement basis under coherent control\u2014every swap in the literature uses a fixed Bell basis.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only (i) one SPDC pair_source and one SPDC idler mode for the two links, (ii) one single_emitter as the control qubit, (iii) a static linear\u2010optical network mixing the two ancilla modes with the control photon to effect a controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement, and (iv) post-selection on two heralding detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a controlled\u2010basis entanglement\u2010swap primitive.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors as follows (dual\u2010rail encodings):\n \u2022 Control qubit (emitter) \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon A_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 2  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon B_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 3  \n \u2022 Idler photons of the two SPDC links are at nodes A (mode 4) and B (mode 5)  \n \u2022 Two ancilla detectors (6,7) herald the Bell\u2010measurement outcome.\n\nGoal:  \nStart with an SPDC\u2010generated Bell pair between modes [2,4] (weak\u2010excitation) and another between [3,5]. It is a true network transformation (routing entanglement), uses only pair_sources + single_emitters + static linear optics + post-selection, and scales to 2\u207f ports.  \n    b) The conditional teleportation has conceptual overlap with controlled-swap/switch examples we tried.  \n    c) The fusion/swap is really just two known primitives chained in one circuit \u2013 essentially state-generation of a 4-photon GHZ-like state.  \n  Step 3: The programmable multi-branch entanglement router (option a) is the winner: it clearly unites weak SPDC pairs and strong-coupling emitters in a scalable network primitive that Pytheus can optimize.  \n  Step 4: Novel because Pytheus has never been tasked with routing the SPDC signal to more than two outputs under coherent emitter control\u2014this opens up a family of 2\u207f-port entanglement-distribution devices.  \n  Step 5: Feasible in Pytheus: one SPDC pair_source produces the Bell pair, n single_emitters provide 2n control rails, a static interferometer mixes the control and signal rails, and 2\u207f heralding detectors post-select successful routing\u2014no dynamic feedback, cavities, or forbidden hyper-entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a programmable 4-branch entanglement router (generalizable to 2\u207f branches) that coherently directs one photon of an SPDC Bell pair to one of four recipients under the control of two on-demand single-photon emitters.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2022 SPDC pair_source S generates a Bell pair in modes (S_sig, S_idl).  \n\u2022 Two single_photon_emitters E1 and E2 each prepare one qubit in dual-rail superposition (control registers C1, C2).  \n\u2022 A fixed linear-optical network interferes the three \u201cdata\u201d modes\u2014S_sig, C1-rails, C2-rails\u2014so that on a successful heralding click at detectors H0,H1,H2,H3 the signal photon emerges in exactly one of four output dual-rail pairs:\n   \u2013 if (C1,C2)=|00\u27e9 \u2192 output A  \n   \u2013 if (C1,C2)=|01\u27e9 \u2192 output B  \n   \u2013 if (C1,C2)=|10\u27e9 \u2192 output C  \n   \u2013 if (C1,C2)=|11\u27e9 \u2192 output D  \nMeanwhile the SPDC idler remains at a \u201cstationary\u201d node X.  \nConditioned on the herald, the final joint state across (C1,C2,output-rails,X) is\n  (|00\u27e9_C\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,X} + |01\u27e9_C\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B,X}\n   + |10\u27e9_C\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C,X} + |11\u27e9_C\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{D,X})/2.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [ S (pair_source) ]   [ E1 (emitter) ]   [ E2 (emitter) ]  \n  Interferometer:  \u2500\u2500 static multi-input, multi-output mixing network \u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:    [0(A0)][1(A1)] [2(B0)][3(B1)] [4(C0)][5(C1)] [6(D0)][7(D1)] [8,9,10,11(heralds H0\u2013H3)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"4-branch entanglement router: SPDC signal steered by 2 emitters\",\n  foldername:         \"4branch_router\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        50,\n  ftol: multi-branch programmable entanglement router as a quantum-network primitive.  \n\u2022 Seamlessly blends a weak-excitation SPDC Bell source with deterministic single-photon emitters for control.     "output": "Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new network\u2010transformation primitive\u2014neither simple state\u2010generation nor a repeat of known swaps or routers\u2014that (1) mixes SPDC (weak\u2010excitation) and single\u2010emitter (strong\u2010coupling) resources, (2) uses only static linear optics + post\u2010selection (Pytheus\u2019s sweet spot), and (3) transforms incoming entanglement rather than merely creating it.  \nEntanglement purification fits: it \u201cconsumes\u201d two incoming Bell\u2010pairs and outputs one higher\u2010quality Bell\u2010pair conditioned on measurement. No previous Pytheus design implements purification. By using two SPDC pair_sources for the noisy pairs and two single_photon_emitters as ancilla photons for the parity\u2010check measurement, we realize the BBPSSW\u2010style parity\u2010projection purification in one static interferometer. The post\u2010selected event projects the two idler photons into a purified Bell pair. This is a network transformation, not mere state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a post\u2010selected entanglement\u2010purification node that consumes two SPDC\u2010generated Bell pairs and two on\u2010demand emitter photons to herald a purified Bell pair.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors (dual\u2010rail qubits) as follows:\n \u2022 SPDC Pair 1 (S1) idler \u2192 mode A (detector 0)  \n   SPDC Pair 1 signal \u2192 mode B1 (detector 1)  \n \u2022 SPDC Pair 2 (S2) idler \u2192 mode C (detector 2)  \n   SPDC Pair 2 signal \u2192 mode B2 (detector 3)  \n \u2022 Ancilla emitters: E1 \u2192 mode E1a (detector 4), E2 \u2192 mode E2a (detector 5)  \n \u2022 Two heralding detectors (post\u2010select on parity outcome) \u2192 modes H1 (6), H2 (7)\n\nGoal:\n\u2022 S1, S2 each emit a Bell\u2010pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9: (A,B1) and (C,B2).  \n\u2022 At node B, we perform a parity\u2010check on (B1,B2) by interfering them with ancilla photons from E1,E2 in a static linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2022 Conditioned on a two\u2010click event on {H1,H2}, modes A and C (the idlers) are projected onto the purified Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,C}.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [ S1 (pair_source) ]   [ S2 (pair_source) ]   [ E1 (emitter) ]   [ E2 (emitter) ]  \n  Linear optics: \u2500\u2500 central interferometer mixing B1,B2,E1a,E2a for parity measurement \u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:    [0(A)] [1(B1)] [2(C)] [3(B2)] [4(E1a)] [5(E2a)] [6(H1)] [7(H2)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Post\u2010selected entanglement purification via parity check\",\n  foldername:         \"ent_purify_node\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [S1_index, S2_index],\n  single_emitters:    [E1_index, E2_index],\n  in_nodes:           [],             # resources come from sources\n  out_nodes:          [0,2],          # idler modes A (0) & C (2) are purified outputs\n  target_quantum:     [\"00\",\"11\"],    # purified Bell \u2012 parity even\n  removed_connections:[\n    # forbid S1\u2192B2 and S2\u2192B1 to prevent cross\u2010leaks\n    [3, S1_index], [1, S2_index],\n    # forbid emitters feeding idlers A,C directly\n    [0, E1_index], [2, E1_index], [0, E2_index], [2, E2_index]\n  ],\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy this is novel and feasible:\n\u2022 Network transformation: it consumes two incoming entangled links and outputs one purified link\u2014this is entanglement purification, not mere state generation.  \n\u2022 Combines weak\u2010excitation SPDC sources for the noisy Bell pairs with strong\u2010coupling single\u2010photon emitters as ancillas for the parity\u2010check measurement.  \n\u2022 Uses only static linear optics and post\u2010selection\u2014Pytheus\u2019s native toolbox, no dynamic feedback or forbidden encodings.  \n\u2022 Expandable: one can chain multiple purification nodes or interleave purification & swapping to study resource trade\u2010offs in quantum\u2010repeater chains.  \n\u2022 Theory impact: yields a family of analytically tractable purification\u2010swap protocols, opening PRL\u2010worthy questions on optimal emitter vs SPDC resource allocation in long\u2010distance networks."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Three-Node Linear-Optical Violation of the Bilocality Inequality\n\nAbstract: We propose a bilocality-test network in which two independent probabilistic entangled-photon-pair sources feed a static partial Bell-state analyzer at a central node B, while peripheral nodes A and C perform fixed-basis single-qubit measurements conditioned on ancilla-heralded joint outcomes at B. The experiment explicitly targets the conditional A\u2013C correlations\u2014tagged by B\u2019s heralding pattern\u2014to achieve a maximal violation of the bilocality inequality, thereby demonstrating genuine non-bilocal quantum correlations beyond standard two-party Bell tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Photonic Magic-Square Contextuality Test via Overlapping Bell-Fusions\n\nMini-abstract: We propose an integrated eight-photon experiment on a nanoscale waveguide circuit that implements the Peres\u2013Mermin magic square through four overlapping linear-optics Bell-fusion measurements arranged in a square topology, with enforced adjacency constraints to reveal true contextuality. By post-selecting the four target 8-bit click patterns 11001100, 00110011, 10101010, and 01010101\u2014which satisfy the square\u2019s row/column parity constraints\u2014this scheme directly tests a commuting-observables contextuality scenario inaccessible to concatenated Bell analyses.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Z\u2083 Topological Teleportation of a Qutrit via Triple-Path Superposition\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate an all-linear-optical protocol that teleports an arbitrary input qutrit |\u03c8\u27e9 from source node S to the target qutrit at node T by coherently superposing three disjoint Bell-swap entanglement paths through intermediate nodes A, B, and C.  Post-selected detection of one photon per ancilla and one click at T heralds a U_Z\u2083 phase imprint diag(1,e^{2\u03c0i/3},e^{4\u03c0i/3}) on the teleported qutrit basis {\u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9,\u22232\u27e9}, directly encoding the network\u2019s Z\u2083 loop homology class as a genuine higher-order topological invariant of the teleportation channel.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. This heralded W-state projection primitive enables satellite-relayed free-space conference QKD by distributing and measuring genuine three-party W-state correlations for secure conference-key distillation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. By combining two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a single-photon input qubit and a control ancilla in a fixed linear-optical interferometer, we perform Bell-state measurements and post-select on \u201c+\u201d outcomes to herald a coherent superposition of the ES\u2192QT and QT\u2192ES sequences, all without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nTeleportation-Based Detection of Flat-Band Topology in a Photonic Creutz Ladder  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a PyTheus-compatible entanglement-swapping protocol on a two-leg photonic Creutz ladder with tunable imaginary diagonal couplings to realize topologically trivial and nontrivial regimes. By performing sequential Bell-state measurements at each intermediate rung, a single-photon qubit is teleported end to end, and the resulting teleportation fidelity as a function of the cross-to-leg coupling ratio unambiguously signals the ladder\u2019s flat-band topological phase transition.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Entanglement Swapping in a 2D Non-Hermitian Topological Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a purely static linear-optical network\u2014a 2\u00d72 near-neighbor non-Hermitian photonic lattice with engineered loss and beam-splitter couplings\u2014to perform topologically-protected, heralded entanglement swapping between corner boundary modes via interior ancilla sites E and F.  Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Swapping Interferometry for Z\u2082-Flux Detection in a Photonic Square Loop\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nIn the Z\u2082-Flux Entanglement Swapping on a Photonic Square Loop protocol, four probabilistic photon-pair sources are placed on the edges of a square with static phase shifters, and Bell-state measurements at two opposite corners generate two coherent entanglement-swapping paths whose interference amplitude encodes the sum of the four link phases around the loop. Instead of discarding these ancillas, a fixed Bell\u2010type measurement on three ancilla detectors (6,7,8) \u201cunlocks\u201d a Bell component (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2 on the target modes 0 and 3\u2014even for damping rates that individually preclude entanglement\u2014thereby directly probing resource\u2010theoretic superactivation in a minimal linear\u2010optics network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Nonlocal SWAP Gate Between Remote Photonic Qubits\n\nMini-Abstract: We target the realization of a fully heralded nonlocal SWAP gate between two unknown photonic qubits |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9_B at node B using only static linear optics, probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources, and post-selected detection. By performing Bell-state projections between time-evolved modes at layers k and N\u2013k and recording the swapped correlation rates as k is varied, one directly reconstructs the Floquet winding number using only linear-optical elements and post-selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Third-Order Holonomy in a Borromean-Loop Teleportation Network\n\nMini-abstract: We present the Borromean-Loop Teleportation Network\u2014a measurement-only, linear-optical scheme in which three independent photonic qubits (\u03c8A, \u03c8B, \u03c8C) are teleported via three interlinked Bell-measurement loops (LA, LB, LC) threaded by synthetic Abelian fluxes \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Researcher: Here is a concrete proposal for Pytheus to design a hybrid-regime teleportation network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to teleport an unknown qubit at node A (detector 0) to node C (detector 1).  \n\u2013 The Bell measurement at A is implemented by two weak-excitation SPDC pair sources whose photons meet in a small linear-optics network and are post-selected on four ancilla detectors (2,3,4,5).  \n\u2013 The entangled resource between B and C is generated by two on-demand single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter coupling), each feeding into modes that are combined interferometrically before reaching detectors at B\u2019s station and C\u2019s output port.  \n\u2013 We enforce that no SPDC source directly populates C and no single-emitter directly populates A by using `removed_connections`.  \n\u2013 Upon coincidence detection in the four ancilla modes, the state at A is teleported to C.  \n  \nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n  emitters/sources: [SPDC1][SPDC2]   [SE1][SE2]  \n  interferometer :   [  Bell-meas unit  ]   [  resource-prep unit ]  \n  detectors       : [0 (A)] [1 (C)] [2][3][4][5 (ancillas)]  \n  \nConfig for Pytheus:\n{\n In the computational basis this defines the 4-qubit \u201cbutterfly\u201d mapping  \n  |00\u27e9\u2192|00\u27e9_out,  |01\u27e9\u2192|10\u27e9_out,  |10\u27e9\u2192|01\u27e9_out,  |11\u27e9\u2192|11\u27e9_out.  \n\nImplementation ingredients:\n  \u2022 Two weak-excitation SPDC sources (S1, S2) each emit a Bell pair: S1 connects modes [0,A\u2032] and S2 connects [1,C\u2032].  \n  \u2022 Two on-demand single-photon emitters (SE1, SE2) generate ancilla photons in modes B\u2032 and D\u2032 to mediate two simultaneous Bell measurements (one on A\u2032\u2013B\u2032, one on C\u2032\u2013D\u2032).  \n  \u2022 A fixed linear-optical network mixes these six modes and routes them into detectors [0,1,2,3] for the logical qubits and four ancilla detectors [4\u20137] for heralding.  \n  \u2022 We forbid any SPDC source to feed directly into the wrong Bell\u2010measurement port (use `removed_connections` to exclude edges S1\u2192D\u2032, S2\u2192B\u2032).  \n  \u2022 Condition on four-fold coincidences in the ancillas: the heralded event completes two teleportations in crossed order, achieving the butterfly map.  \n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Sources:      [S1]   [S2]   [SE1]   [SE2]  \n  Linear optics:[     central interferometer for two Bell projections     ]  \n  Detectors:    [0(A_in)] [1(C_in)] [2(B_out)] [3(D_out)] [4][5][6][7 (ancillas)]  \n\nExample pytheus config snippet:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum butterfly: cross\u2010teleportation network coding\",\n  foldername:         \"butterfly-code\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            4,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  in_nodes:           [0,1],\n  out_nodes:          [2,3],\n  target_quantum:     [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"],\n  single_emitters:    [S1_index, S2_index],     # There is no new network function or resource advantage beyond that prior suggestion.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This does not constitute a novel network primitive beyond the ensemble\u2019s hybrid SPDC\u2013emitter swapping. Two SPDC pair_sources generate Bell\u2010pairs on links A\u2013B and B\u2013C; a single\u2010photon emitter prepares the control qubit |+\u27e9_c. A static linear\u2010optical network routes the Bell\u2010measurements in two orders conditioned on the control path, and two heralding detectors signal success. The final joint state of (control, A_out, C_out) is\n   (|0\u27e9_c \u2297 |\u03a6+\u27e9_{A,C} + |1\u27e9_c \u2297 |\u03a6\u2212\u27e9_{A,C})/\u221a2.\nThis realizes indefinite causal order of two entanglement swaps in one post\u2010selected circuit, combining weak\u2010excitation SPDC and strong\u2010coupling emitters without dynamic control.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:          [SPDC1]   [SPDC2]   [Emitter_C]  \n  Linear optics:    [    central interferometer implementing controlled\u2010order swapping & Bell\u2010measurement    ]  \n  Detectors:        [0(C0)] [1(C1)] [2(A_out0)] [3(A_out1)] [4(C_out0)] [5(C_out1)] [6,7 (heralds)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Quantum switch: superposed\u2010order entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ent_swap_switch\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [S1_index, S2_index],\n  single_emitters:    [C_index],\n  in_nodes:           [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  out_nodes:          [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  target_quantum:     [ \n                       \"000000\",  # |0\u27e9_c |00\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"011011\",  # |0\u27e9_c |11\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"100000\",  # |1\u27e9_c |00\u27e9_{A,C}\n                       \"-111011\"  # - In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). It is not in the existing list (which has SPDC\u2010only qutrit swaps or single\u2010emitter qutrit swaps), and Pytheus can handle it (pair_sources + single_emitters + static interferometer + post-selection).  \n  Step 3: Pick (c) as the most promising: it\u2019s a fundamental repeater\u2010link primitive, generalizable to N hops by trading SPDC sources for emitters, and independent of implementation success.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus design (or published linear\u2010optical experiment) demonstrates an entanglement swap where one of the two Bell\u2010pairs is generated by two on\u2010demand single\u2010photon emitters, thereby halving the probabilistic\u2010ancilla cost.  \n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because we only require: (i) one SPDC pair_source, (ii) two single_emitters that Pytheus can route and interfere to form a Bell\u2010pair, (iii) a static linear\u2010optical network mixing the three \u201cdata\u201d photons plus two ancilla modes, and (iv) post-selection on two heralding detectors\u2014no dynamic feed-forward or forbidden state-generation.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a concrete Pytheus target for a hybrid entanglement\u2010swap link:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to entangle node A (detector 0) and node D (detector 1) by swapping two Bell\u2010pairs:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010pair 1 (weak-excitation): an SPDC source S emits two photons into modes [A1, X].  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2010pair 2 (strong\u2010coupling): two on-demand single\u2010photon emitters E1, E2 each emit one photon; Pytheus will optimize a small interferometer + post-selection on those two photons to produce a Bell\u2010pair into modes [Y, D1].  \nA single Bell\u2010measurement is then performed on the two \u201cmiddle\u201d photons in modes [X,Y] via a linear\u2010optical mixer and two heralding detectors (2, 3). Fusion\u2010swap collapses to two known primitives (fusion and swap) and feels like state\u2010generation of a four\u2010photon GHZ\u2010type state.  \n  Step 3: The controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (option 1) wins: it\u2019s a fundamental network\u2010measurement primitive that can be generalized to N bases, nodes, and higher\u2010dimensional systems.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no Pytheus experiment so far implements entanglement swapping with a measurement basis under coherent control\u2014every swap in the literature uses a fixed Bell basis.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only (i) one SPDC pair_source and one SPDC idler mode for the two links, (ii) one single_emitter as the control qubit, (iii) a static linear\u2010optical network mixing the two ancilla modes with the control photon to effect a controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement, and (iv) post-selection on two heralding detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a controlled\u2010basis entanglement\u2010swap primitive.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors as follows (dual\u2010rail encodings):\n \u2022 Control qubit (emitter) \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon A_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 2  \n \u2022 Link\u2010photon B_in from SPDC \u2192 mode 3  \n \u2022 Idler photons of the two SPDC links are at nodes A (mode 4) and B (mode 5)  \n \u2022 Two ancilla detectors (6,7) herald the Bell\u2010measurement outcome.\n\nGoal:  \nStart with an SPDC\u2010generated Bell pair between modes [2,4] (weak\u2010excitation) and another between [3,5]. A single\u2010photon emitter (strong coupling) prepares control |+\u27e9_c across [0,1]. A static interferometer mixes modes 0\u20133 such that detection in {6,7} implements a Bell measurement on [2,3] in basis  \n  \u201c\u03a6\u00b1\u201d if control = |0\u27e9,  \n  \u201c\u03a8\u00b1\u201d if control = |1\u27e9.  \nConditioning on a particular heralding click yields the final joint state on (control,[4,5]):\n   (|0\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{4,5}  +  |1\u27e9_c\u2297|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9_{4,5})/\u221a2.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:      [ SPDC_pair ]   [ single_photon_emitter ]  \n  Linear optics:  \u2500\u2500 central interferometer effecting controlled\u2010basis Bell\u2010measurement \u2500\u2500  \n  Detectors:    [0][1 (control)] [2][3 (swap inputs)] [4][5 (outputs A,B)] [6][7 (heralds)]\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Controlled\u2010basis entanglement swap (SPDC + emitter)\",\n  foldername:         \"ctrl_basis_swap\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [SPDC_index],\n  single_emitters:    [Emitter_index],\n  in_nodes:           [],         # sources feed inputs directly\n  out_nodes:          [0,1,4,5],  # control dual-rail + output dual-rails at A,B\n  target_quantum:     [\n    \"100100\",  # |0>_c |00>_{AB}  \u2192 1 0 |1 0|1 0 \n    \"101011\",  # |0>_c |11>_{AB}\n    \"010110\",  # |1>_c |01>_{AB}\n    \"011001\"   # |1>_c |10>_{AB}  (represents |\u03a8+>)\n  ],\n  removed_connections: [\n    # forbid direct SPDC\u2192control and emitter\u2192swap-output leaks\n    [0, SPDC_index], [1, SPDC_index],\n    [4, Emitter_index], [5, Emitter_index]\n  ],\n  imaginary:          true,       # necessary for implementing \u03a8 basis\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2022 It defines a new network primitive: entanglement swapping with a coherently controlled measurement basis, rather than a fixed Bell basis.  \n\u2022 Combines weak\u2010excitation SPDC resources for link pairs with a deterministic emitter qubit control.  \n\u2022 Uses only static linear optics and post\u2010selection\u2014no dynamic feedback or hyper\u2010entanglement.  \n\u2022 Can be extended to multiple bases, higher dimensions, or cascaded to probe adaptive network protocols.  \n\u2022 The theoretical significance lies in exploring the quantum\u2010coherent interplay between choice of network measurement and resulting entanglement\u2014ripe for a theory paper in PRL.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled-basis swap duplicates the ensemble\u2019s telecom-band example of routing between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements via a superposed control photon. It is a true network transformation (routing entanglement), uses only pair_sources + single_emitters + static linear optics + post-selection, and scales to 2\u207f ports.  \n    b) The conditional teleportation has conceptual overlap with controlled-swap/switch examples we tried.  \n    c) The fusion/swap is really just two known primitives chained in one circuit \u2013 essentially state-generation of a 4-photon GHZ-like state.  \n  Step 3: The programmable multi-branch entanglement router (option a) is the winner: it clearly unites weak SPDC pairs and strong-coupling emitters in a scalable network primitive that Pytheus can optimize.  \n  Step 4: Novel because Pytheus has never been tasked with routing the SPDC signal to more than two outputs under coherent emitter control\u2014this opens up a family of 2\u207f-port entanglement-distribution devices.  \n  Step 5: Feasible in Pytheus: one SPDC pair_source produces the Bell pair, n single_emitters provide 2n control rails, a static interferometer mixes the control and signal rails, and 2\u207f heralding detectors post-select successful routing\u2014no dynamic feedback, cavities, or forbidden hyper-entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a programmable 4-branch entanglement router (generalizable to 2\u207f branches) that coherently directs one It generalizes the two-destination router and opens a family of 2\u207f-destination network devices.  \n  Step 5: Feasible in Pytheus since it only uses:  \n      \u2022 One SPDC pair_source (weak-excitation)  \n      \u2022 Two single_emitters (strong-coupling)  \n      \u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer mixing three data modes + two control rails  \n      \u2022 Four heralding detectors  \n      \u2022 No dynamic feedback, cavities, or forbidden encodings.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: a programmable four-branch entanglement router that coherently directs one photon of an SPDC Bell pair to one of four output stations, under the control of two on-demand emitter qubits.\n\nExplanation:\nWe label detectors in dual-rail as follows:\n \u2022 Control qubits:\n   \u2013 E1 \u2192 modes (C10=0, C11=1)\n   \u2013 E2 \u2192 modes (C20=2, C21=3)\n \u2022 SPDC Bell pair S \u2192 modes (S_sig\u2192signal, S_idl\u2192idler)\n \u2022 Output stations (A,B,C,D) each in dual rails:\n   \u2013 A: (0,1), B: (2,3), C: (4,5), D: (6,7)\n \u2022 Heralds: (8,9,10,11)\n\nGoal:\nS creates |\u03a6+\u27e9_{signal,idler}. weak\u2010excitation SPDC pairs + on\u2010demand single emitters (static optics + post\u2010selection only):\n    a) A network\u2010superposition toggle: the emitter qubit coherently decides whether to perform an entanglement swap at the intermediate node B (turning two SPDC links AB+BC into one AC link) or to leave both links intact\u2014yielding a superposition of two network topologies.\n    b) A three\u2010way \u201cfusion\u2010router\u201d that uses one SPDC and two emitters to combine and then split entanglement among three clients in a single circuit.\n    c) A \u201cnested\u2010swap\u201d chain in superposition: simultaneously swap two SPDC links in two different orders, controlled by an emitter.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    a) The toggle\u2010switch is not in the existing list (all swaps are fixed), is a true network transformation (no pure state prep), and uses only (i) SPDC pair_sources, (ii) single_emitters, (iii) a static interferometer mixing outputs + ancillas, (iv) post\u2010selection. \n    b) The three\u2010way fusion\u2010router reduces to state generation or teleporter.\n    c) The nested\u2010swap superposition is an indefinite\u2010order switch\u2014already covered.\n  Step 3: Choose (a): the controlled\u2010topology superposition (swap\u2010or\u2010no\u2010swap) toggle.\n  Step 4: Novel because no Pytheus design entangles a control qubit with a superposition of two distinct network connectivities (AB+BC vs AC). \n  Step 5: Feasible in Pytheus: specify two SPDC pair_sources, one single_photon_emitter control qubit, static linear optics + two heralding detectors, target quantum on 5 qubits\u2014fits Pytheus\u2019s toolbox exactly.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for Pytheus \u2013 a controlled\u2010topology entanglement\u2010swap toggle:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want a single static circuit that, conditionally on a control qubit |+\u27e9_c (prepared by a single\u2010photon emitter E), either (i) leaves two SPDC links AB & BC intact, or (ii) performs a Bell\u2010swap at B to yield a single link AC. The result is a coherent superposition of the two network graphs:\n\n  |0\u27e9_c \u2297 (|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,B1} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B2,C})\n+ |1\u27e9_c \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{A,C} \u2297 |00\u27e9_{B1,B2}.\n\nWe label five qubit\u2010modes / detectors:\n  0 = control qubit  (emitter E),\n  1 = node A (SPDC1 idler),\n  2 = node B1 (SPDC1 signal),\n  3 = node B2 (SPDC2 signal),\n  4 = node C (SPDC2 idler),\n  5\u20136 = two heralding detectors for the swap measurement.\n\nSources:\n  \u2013 SPDC1 \u2192 generates Bell pair across modes [1,2] (A,B1).\n  \u2013 SPDC2 \u2192 generates Bell pair across modes [3,4] (B2,C).\n  \u2013 Emitter E \u2192 prepares |+\u27e9_c in mode 0.\n\nStatic interferometer:\n  Mixes modes [0,2,3] plus two ancilla modes.  \n  Conditional on clicks in detectors 5&6, Pytheus engineer a network that effects \u201cdo nothing\u201d on (2,3) if the photon is in mode 0, and \u201cswap\u2010Bell\u2010measure (2,3)\u201d if in mode 0\u2032 (the other rail) \u2013 all embedded in one multiport.\n\nTarget quantum (in qubit order [0,1,2,3,4]):\n  \u201c00000\u201d   \u2190 E=0, A=0,B1=0,B2=0,C=0  \n  \u201c00011\u201d   \u2190 E=0, A=0,B1=0,B2=1,C=1  \n  \u201c01100\u201d   \u2190 E=0, A=1,B1=1,B2=0,C=0  \n  \u201c01111\u201d   \u2190 E=0, A=1,B1=1,B2=1,C=1  \n  \u201c10000\u201d   \u2190 E=1, A=0,B1=0,B2=0,C=0  \n  \u201c11001\u201d   \u2190 E=1, A=1,B1=0,B2=0,C=1  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"Controlled\u2010topology swap toggle: preserve AB+BC vs swap to AC in superposition\",\n  foldername:         \"swap_toggle_network\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        40,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [0,1],          # control + A,B1,B2,C\n  target_quantum:     [\"00000\",\"00011\",\"01100\",\"01111\",\"10000\",\"11001\"],\n  removed_connections:[\n    # forbid SPDC1 \u2192 C and SPDC2 \u2192 A to enforce link separations\n    [4,0],[1,1]\n    #     "output": "Thought:\nI\u2019ll propose a genuinely new network primitive\u2014a \u201cone-step hybrid repeater node\u201d that simultaneously purifies two noisy SPDC links and swaps them into a high-fidelity entangled link, all in one static circuit.  It combines:\n \u2022 Two SPDC pair_sources (weak-excitation regime) providing two noisy Bell pairs on A\u2013B\u2081 and B\u2082\u2013C.  \n \u2022 Two on-demand single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter coupling) as ancillas to do purification (parity check) and to enable the Bell-swap measurement in one go.  \n \u2022 A single static linear-optical interferometer mixing the four \u201cmiddle\u201d modes (B\u2081, B\u2082, plus the two emitter-ancilla rails) and three heralding detectors.  \n \u2022 Post-selection on herald clicks yields a single purified, swapped Bell pair between A and C.  \nThis is a network transformation (integrated purification+swap), not mere state generation, uses only SPDC + emitters + static optics + post-selection (Pytheus-compatible), and can be generalized to chains of \u201chybrid repeater nodes\u201d trading off SPDC vs emitter resources.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target for an integrated purification-and-swap repeater node:\n\nExplanation:\nWe have two SPDC sources S1, S2 and two single-photon emitters E1, E2.  The goal is to consume the noisy Bell pairs on links A\u2013B\u2081 and B\u2082\u2013C and, in one step, output a purified Bell pair on A\u2013C.\n\nMode labeling (dual-rail qubits):\n \u2022 A (SPDC1 idler) \u2192 detectors [0,1]  \n \u2022 B\u2081 (SPDC1 signal) \u2192 mode 2  \n \u2022 B\u2082 (SPDC2 signal) \u2192 mode 3  \n \u2022 C (SPDC2 idler) \u2192 detectors [4,5]  \n \u2022 E1 ancilla rails \u2192 modes 6,7  \n \u2022 E2 ancilla rails \u2192 modes 8,9  \n \u2022 Herald detectors \u2192 modes 10,11,12  \n\nSetup:\n  Sources:     [ S1(pair_source) ] [ S2(pair_source) ] [ E1(emitter) ] [ E2(emitter) ]  \n  Interferometer: a single 6\u00d76 multiport that mixes B\u2081, B\u2082, E1-rails, E2-rails  \n  Detectors:   [0(A0)][1(A1)] [4(C0)][5(C1)] [10][11][12] (heralds)\n\nOperation:\n \u2022 S1, S2 each emit |\u03a6+\u27e9 (noisy) on (A,B\u2081) and (B\u2082,C).  \n \u2022 E1,E2 each emit one ancilla photon.  \n \u2022 The central multiport is tuned so that:\n    \u2013 A parity check on (B\u2081,B\u2082) is performed via interference with E1,E2: click on two of {10,11,12} \u21d2 even parity (purification).  \n    \u2013 Simultaneously, a Bell-swap measurement on (B\u2081,B\u2082) is realized (the same interference) \u21d2 entanglement swapping.  \n \u2022 Condition on a specific triple-click pattern in modes (10,11,12) \u21d2 idlers A & C collapse onto a purified Bell pair |\u03a6+\u27e9_{A,C}.\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description:        \"One-step hybrid repeater: purification + entanglement swap\",\n  foldername:         \"hybrid_repeater_node\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        50,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  num_anc:            3,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:            20,\n  pair_sources:       [S1_index, S2_index],\n  single_emitters:    [E1_index, E2_index],\n  in_nodes:           [],               # resources come from sources\n  out_nodes:          [0,1,4,5],        # A and C dual\u2010rail outputs\n  target_quantum:     [\"00\",\"11\"],      # purified Bell on A\u2013C\n  removed_connections:[\n    # prevent S1\u2192C and S2\u2192A leaks\n    [4, S1_index],[5, S1_index],[0, S2_index],[1, S2_index],\n    # prevent ancilla rails feeding A,C directly\n    [0, E1_index],[1, E1_index],[4, E1_index],[5, E1_index],\n    [0, E2_index],[1, E2_index],[4, E2_index],[5, E2_index]\n  ],\n  number_resolving:   true,\n  unicolor:           false\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 It realizes a fundamentally new repeater\u2010node primitive: entanglement purification and swapping in one shot, reducing resource overhead and latency.  \n \u2022 Merges weak\u2010excitation SPDC Bell\u2010pairs with strong\u2010coupling emitter ancillas in a single static circuit\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s domain.  \n \u2022 Generalizable: by concatenating such nodes or varying ancilla counts, one can map out the trade-off between SPDC vs emitter resources in long-distance quantum networks.  \n \u2022 Opens theory questions on optimal hybrid repeater architectures and resource scaling."
